intro: Microchloa, commonly known as the grass-like plant of the family Poaceae, is a genus of small, often epiphytic plants. These plants are characterized by their compact growth form and the presence of specialized structures called "microchloa" which are involved in nitrogen fixation. They are typically found in tropical and subtropical regions, often growing on tree trunks or rocks. Microchloa species are known for their ability to thrive in nutrient-poor environments due to their symbiotic relationship with cyanobacteria. Their unique morphology and ecological adaptations make them an important component of certain ecosystems.
